protocol_name: Field sampling of root-associated microbes for DNA/RNA extraction
protocol_name_html: Field sampling of root-associated microbes for DNA/RNA extraction
description: This protocol describes a procedure for sampling plant roots in the field for future DNA and RNA extraction for microbiome analysis. The protocol is deliberately designed to be simple and requires no electronic equipment. Root samples are preserved in LifeGuard Soil Preservation Solution for protecting against nucleic acid degradation.
before_start:
Clean spatulas using 70% ethanol

 
 
 
G

keywords: soil, sampling, root, rhizosphere, RNA, DNA, LifeGuard, preservation solution, field work, plant
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data:
Sample a triplicate of plant individuals spaced out a few metres apart from each other

Make sure you are reall sampling individual plants and not offshoots of the same plant
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Sample a triplicate of plant individuals spaced out a few metres apart from each other

Make sure you are reall sampling individual plants and not offshoots of the same plant

components.data:
Using a garden trowel, carefully dig out the plants while keeping the root system intact (as much as possible, of course)
 
 
 
G
M
T
 
           
 
 
 
Text-to-speech function is limited to 200 characters
 
  Options : History : Feedback : Donate Close

components.data:
While holding the plant by the shoot, shake the root system hard enough so that all loose soil is removed from it.
Take care to damage the plant as little as possible
You can use a spatula to remove large soil aggregates that are attached to the roots
 
 
 
G
M
T
 
           
 
 
 
Text-to-speech function is limited to 200 characters
 
  Options : History : Feedback : Donate Close

components.data:
From the remaining root system (plus soil particles plus attached to the roots), trim a 'representative sample' of roots using scissors or scalpel

It is usually best to trim the roots onto a  piece of paper towel
 
 
 
G
M
T
 
           
 
 
 
Text-to-speech function is limited to 200 characters
 
  Options : History : Feedback : Donate Close

source_data.protocol_name: Field sampling of root-associated microbes for DNA/RNA extraction
source_data.protocol_name_html: Field sampling of root-associated microbes for DNA/RNA extraction
source_data.annotation:
Make sure the roots do not take up more than 1/2-2/3 of the volume

It is of course possible to split each sample into several separate tubes, depending on the specific type of roots, and submerge each with LifeGuard solution
source_data.thread_text:
Make sure the roots do not take up more than 1/2-2/3 of the volume

It is of course possible to split each sample into several separate tubes, depending on the specific type of roots, and submerge each with LifeGuard solution
source_data.body:
Make sure the roots do not take up more than 1/2-2/3 of the volume

It is of course possible to split each sample into several separate tubes, depending on the specific type of roots, and submerge each with LifeGuard solution

components.data:
Add as much LifeGuard solution so that the sample is submerged in about twice of its volume (about 1.0 – 1.5 ml)
Best is to use a disposable Pasteur pipette for dispensing the solution
 
 
 
G
M
T
 
           
 
 
 
Text-to-speech function is limited to 200 characters
 
  Options : History : Feedback : Donate Close

components.data:
Place the tubes in cooling (around 4 °C) and keep them cooled until you reach the lab. The solution will protect nucleic acids even at room temperature for several days, but cooling is preferred
 
 
 
G
M
T

components.data: In the lab, store the samples in a freezer (-20 – -80 °C)
components.name: Description
